---
title: "Bar Charts in ggplot With Multiple Outcomes"
author: "Andy Grogan-Kaylor"
date: "2022-8-1"
categories: [stats]
---


# Setup


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code  code-fold="true" code-summary="Show the code"}
library(ggplot2) # beautiful graphs

library(tidyr) # tidy data
```
:::


# Simulated Data


::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
# A tibble: 3 × 3
      x     y     z
  <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
1     1     4     7
2     2     5     8
3     3     6     3
```
:::
:::


# Reshape Data With `pivot_longer`


::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
# A tibble: 6 × 3
      x newnames newvalues
  <dbl> <chr>        <dbl>
1     1 y                4
2     1 z                7
3     2 y                5
4     2 z                8
5     3 y                6
6     3 z                3
```
:::
:::


# Graphs

## Bar Chart With Stacked Bars

### `geom_bar()`


::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-4-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


### `geom_col()`

By default, `geom_col()` assumes `stat = 'identity'` i.e. `y` is the height of the bar.


::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::
